steps.title: Know your terminology.
steps.content: Know your terminology. Linear equations have distinct components. The variable is the symbol (usually a letter like x or y) for a number you do not yet know. The constant is a number that remains consistent. The coefficient is a number before a variable, which is used to multiply it. [1] X Research source For example, in the linear equation 2x + 4y = 8, x and y are variables. The constant is 8. The numbers 2 and 4 are coefficients.

steps.title: Recognize the form for a system of equations.
steps.content: Recognize the form for a system of equations. A system of equations with two variables can be written as follows: ax + by = p cx + dy = q Any of the constants (p, q) can be zero, with the exception that each equation must have at least one variable (x, y) in it. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Understand matrix equations.
steps.content: Understand matrix equations. When you have a linear system, you can use a matrix to rewrite it, then use the algebraic properties of that matrix to solve it. To rewrite a linear system, you use A to represent the coefficients matrix, C to represent the constants matrix, and X to represent the unknown matrix. [3] X Research source The linear system above, for example, can be rewritten as a matrix equation as follows: A x X = C.

steps.title: Understand elementary operations.
steps.content: Understand elementary operations. You can perform certain operations on a matrix to transform it while keeping it equivalent to the original. These are called elementary operations. To solve a 2x3 matrix, for example, you use elementary row operations to transform the matrix into a triangular one. Elementary operations include: [5] X Research source swapping two rows. multiplying a row by a number different from zero. multiplying one row and then adding to another row.
